title: How to Furnish Your First Home

steps.headline: Bring over and assess what you already have.
steps.description: You won’t have enough to furnish your entire home, but that’s okay. You don’t need to start over from scratch. Arrange all of your old furnishings in your home, thinking about which ones are worth keeping. Try to avoid hanging onto anything broken or things you never plan on using. Sort your items out before you move them to your new home. It may save you some money in moving expenses. You could also sell your old items for extra pocket change to put toward new furniture. Be cautious about throwing away anything useable. That old couch may not be what you want in your new home, but it’s worth keeping if you don’t have a replacement yet.

steps.headline: Go room by room to figure out what you need to buy.
steps.description: Sit in each room for a few minutes. Bring a pad and paper along to write down any furnishings you can think of. Plan out each room as much as you can to keep a running list of what you need to fill the space. Don’t forget to spend time in any smaller areas you have, like foyers and hallways. Focus on small items as well as big ones. Furniture like couches, chairs, and beds are the easiest to put on your list, but get specific. Consider features like appliances, lamps, and picture frames as well.

steps.headline: Rank your rooms by priority according to how often you use them.
steps.description: Aim on furnishing the most used areas of your home first. Typically, the bedroom and living room are the ones to focus on, but it depends on your home. Get the most out of these rooms by decorating them first. Break it down further by ranking the furnishings in each room by necessity. Since you’re going to spend more time in some rooms compared to others, it makes sense to put more effort into decorating them. The side rooms can wait. Furnish them as much as possible for now and add to them over time.

steps.headline: Create a floor plan to figure out how much room you have to work with.
steps.description: If you don’t get a floor plan when you move in, sketch one yourself. Note where the important features are, such as the windows, walls, and vents. If you need to, measure the width and height of these features so you know how much room you have left for furnishings. Use the floor plan as a guide when you’re designing the room and choosing furniture for it. For example, the fixtures determine where you can put certain objects. You wouldn’t put a big bookcase in front of a window or in a room with a low ceiling. Keep in mind that furniture often looks bigger when you get it home than it does at the store. Have your floor plan handy to use as a comparison before making a purchase.

steps.headline: Purchase the most essential items for your main rooms first.
steps.description: The items you use most frequently are the most important to have. As a starting point, look for a bed, a sofa, and a few chairs. You might already have a few of these items. In that case, move on to filling the rooms with less important items like nightstands, cabinets, and decorations. Since the essentials are so important, buy for quality over a quantity. A good mattress with quality sheets will likely last you much longer than a cheap set that gives you back pain. You don’t need a set of uncomfortable chairs, just a few you don’t mind relaxing on. The extra chairs help a lot for times when you have guests over. The amount you need depends on how often you have people over and how many you invite.

steps.headline: Fill in all your rooms bit by bit.
steps.description: After you have a good base setup, start filling in the gaps as your budget allows. When you get a little extra spending money and stumble across something you like, get it for your home. Begin completing rooms with extra furniture, appliances, decorations, and anything else you might need. Taking care of the necessities first gives you more time to save and search for quality furnishings you like. Don’t rush to decorate. You’re better off waiting to find exactly what you need.

steps.headline: Recycle secondhand items to fill rooms at a low cost.
steps.description: Secondhand sources are your new best friend. Once your family knows you are moving, you will probably end up with a lot of spare furniture. Also, check thrift stores, consignment stores, garage sales, estate sales, and online listings. You don’t need to buy new to get something stylish and unique. These sources all sell good furniture at a fraction of the retail price. There is no need to buy furniture in a set. Get your furnishings 1 at a time as you find things you like. Even if you don’t intend on keeping all of these secondhand furnishings long-term, use them to set up your home until you get a chance to replace them. However, don’t take on more than you need.

steps.headline: Refurbish old furniture to make it look new again.
steps.description: Instead of getting rid of that ripped chair or chipped table, fix it up! Many worn-down pieces are still useable with a little care. Reupholster couches and chairs with new fabric and refinish wood. Then, put the money you save toward getting what you really want. Refurbishing furniture does take a little extra time and effort, but it’s often worth it if you want to hang onto something that has gotten plenty of use.

steps.headline: Build your own furniture if you’re handy with crafts.
steps.description: Some pieces of furniture, such as a nice coffee table, come with a big price tag. Break out your drill set and a box of nails for a fun home project. Even if you don’t have much experience, you could save money by making your own table or chair, for example. You will need to get a set of tools and material for building projects, but the cost is typically much less than what you would spend on a new piece of furniture from a box store. Another option is to make your own decorations. If you’re good at sewing, make your own pillows. If you’re good at painting, hang up your paintings to give your home its own unique character.

steps.headline: Wait for new items to go on sale before buying them.
steps.description: If you’re strategic about when you buy new furnishings, you can get more no matter what your budget looks like. Plan out your purchases according to when items are out of season. Winter items go on sale at the beginning of summer, while stores clear out summer items at the end of summer. For example, if you’re looking for indoor furniture, look for sales during the spring. Appliances often go on sale before holidays. You don’t have to wait to purchase items. If something is a necessity, get it as soon as you can. The sales price isn’t as important as the quality.

steps.headline: Replace and throw away items you don’t need.
steps.description: As you set up your new home, you may come across some old items that no longer fit your style. If something clashes with that stylish leather couch you bought, get rid of it! Take advantage of your new space to clear out old junk and dispose of older items you no longer need. Make sure you can’t use older items to furnish other rooms first. If you’re certain you no longer have a use for something, try to get a replacement as needed before disposing of it. Sell or donate good items you no longer need. Another option is to refurbish old furniture to give it a new place in your home.

steps.headline: Choose an overall style to unify your room.
steps.description: Style is a reflection of your personal tastes, so you don’t have to stick to a single one if you don’t want to. However, choosing a style can give a room its own unique atmosphere. If you wish to style your room a certain way, pick furnishings that fit that kind of style. That way, you don’t waste money on decorations you can’t use. For example, you could theme your room around types of furniture. Choose sleek, low-profile furniture for a more modern look, or distressed wood for a shabby chic look. Another option is to style your room around a color theme. Blue and white is a great option for starting a nautical theme. Brown and white is common in a more rustic, farmhouse look.

steps.headline: Decorate around your favorite piece of furniture.
steps.description: Start with the furnishing you like best and make it a focal point of your design. Take cues from that piece and choose decorations that compliment it. You might wish to leave your best or most important furnishing out in the open so guests see it as soon as they enter the room. For example, if you have a stylish sofa, make it stand out. You might leave a black leather sofa against a white wall close to a couple of brown chairs. Add color with plants or art so you don’t take attention away from the sofa.

steps.headline: [Use neutral colors that go with most furnishings and themes.
steps.description: While colors like white and beige may sound kind of bland, they are lifesavers when you’re trying to bring a room together. Stick to light, inoffensive colors to avoid conflicts with whatever furnishings you plan on bringing in. Try painting the walls neutral colors and then spicing up the atmosphere with colorful accents. If you already have a room theme in mind, getting more adventurous is fine. Color your walls red if you like, but add dark-colored furniture to compliment it and create an autumn theme. The best time to remodel the walls and flooring is before you get most of your furnishings in the room. Start with neutral tones if you're still uncertain about what you want to do. You could always repaint later on down the line.

steps.headline: Personalize your room with art and other accent furnishings.
steps.description: Many times, the small details you add have the biggest impact. Accessories like a vibrant piece of art, colorful picture frames, bushy plants, and unique throw pillows are a few examples that brighten up the room. Place these accessories as you after moving the main furnishings into the room. If you’re trying to highlight a piece of furniture, a bright throw pillow will draw your eye toward it, for instance. Even a single accent can pull a room together. It’s all about your personal style. Match the accessories to the rest of your furnishings.

steps.headline: Go for a minimalist route to avoid cluttering your rooms.
steps.description: Minimalism will also save you money when you leave behind those extra furnishings you don’t really need. It isn’t about leaving your rooms empty. The goal is to bring in what you need and move the excess elsewhere. Keep each room neat and organized so it looks its best. Clutter makes your room look too busy. When someone comes into your room, they will focus on certain furnishings, like a bright accent or central piece of furniture. Other furnishings won’t get nearly as much love and could end up looking out of place. If you really don’t have room for something, ask yourself if you need it. Consider throwing it away or giving it away to make space.

steps.headline: Light your rooms with good curtains and bulbs for warmth.
steps.description: Lighting is key for actually getting a chance to appreciate the room you worked hard to decorate. Start out with some decent light bulbs placed in lamps spread out across the room. Also, cover the windows with a matching pair of curtains and shutters to complete the room. Test out your new setup by turning on the lights and seeing how cozy your new room feels. Stay away from fluorescent bulbs, since the blue light they give off is too bright and harsh. LED and halogen bulbs give off a pleasant, warm light. For most rooms, a low-wattage bulb gives off enough light. Think of curtains and shades as extra accent pieces. They add color to a room in addition to controlling light and privacy. For that reason, keep them relatively neutral unless you’re trying to draw attention to them.
